text:
ARTPOP EXPANDS TO INCLUDE HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS
An art contest in which the winning pieces are featured on billboards has been expanded to include high school students.
ArtPop, a public art program started in 2014 by Adams Outdoor Advertising, ArtsQuest and the Lehigh Valley's arts community, highlights local artists. The work of six artists is appearing on Adams Outdoor Advertising billboards this year.
For 2016, the artwork of one Lehigh Valley high school student be showcased on an Adams billboard for a year along with six adult artists chosen in the traditional ArtPop competition. The ArtPop Scholastic Competition is open to students in Lehigh and Northampton counties in grades 9-12. One winner will be chosen by a jury, which also will pick 10 students' artwork to be featured in an exhibition in the ArtsQuest Center at SteelStacks Jan. 16-March 13.
Five adult artists will be chosen by jury, and a People's Choice winner will be picked by a public vote.
"Adams is proud to support Lehigh Valley artists and ArtPop again in 2016," says Adams Outdoor Advertising General Manager Tony Cioffi. "With the huge success of the program last year, we are looking forward to even more submissions and making the decisions of our judges very tough this year."
Jurors are Santa Bannon of Santa Bannon/Fine Art; Kristen Cook, graphic designer, Adams Outdoor Advertising; Randall Forte, executive director, Lehigh Valley Arts Council, and Diane LaBelle, executive director, Lehigh Valley Charter Arts High School.
"What is so great about this project is that it teaches youth the professional approach to art and business," LaBelle says. "It especially dramatizes the connection between artistic creativity and entrepreneurship in the global world of the 21st century."
Artists should submit an image of a two-dimensional or three-dimensional work online at www.bananafactory.org/artpop . Artists should include name, address, email address, title and media of the original work of art, and a one-paragraph biography.
The deadline for students is Dec. 7 and for adult artists Nov. 16. Voting for the People's Choice will be Dec. 8-18. Winners will be announced on Dec. 21.
More info: visit www.bananafactory.org/artpop .
LVAC ARTS RALLY
To celebrate National Arts and Humanities Month, the Lehigh Valley Arts Council will host Arts Count, an arts rally and awards ceremony 5:30-7:30 p.m. Tuesday, at Lehigh Valley Charter High School for the Arts, Third and Polk streets, Bethlehem.
The grant winners of the Pennsylvania Partners in the Arts Project Stream program will be recognized. More than $34,000 in state funds will be awarded to 26 applicants for activities through Aug. 31.
The gathering also celebrates the news and expanded Charter Arts facility in south Bethlehem. Guests can tour the 80,000 square-foot facility, now equipped with a recording studio, a black box studio, four dance studios, expanded art studios and gallery, and a 350-seat performing arts theatre.
Cost: $10; free, Arts Council members and grant recipients. RSVP required.
RSVP: 610-437-5915.
PHILLIPS MILL ART SHOW WINNERS
Several local artists received awards in the 86th annual Phillips Mill Juried Art Exhibition, which runs through Oct. 31.
Quakertown artist Robert Papp won the Patrons Award for painting for "A Study in White," an oil on linen. Charles R. Ross of Schwenksville won for for his watercolor "Spring Burn," and Gary R. Phillips of Green Lane won for the oil painting "The Historian."
Jurors for framed work were artists Barbara Schaff, Elizabeth Osborne and Douglas Wiltraut. The jurors for sculpture were George R. Anthonisen and David Cann.
The show accepts the work of artists living within a 25 mile radius of Phillips Mill. This year 349 works were submitted and 93 framed pieces and 13 pieces of sculpture accepted. There were 19 awards presented and $10,000 in prize money given out.
Phillips Mill's Juried Art Exhibition is open 1-5 p.m. daily at 2619 River Road, New Hope. Admission is $5; $4, seniors; $2, students; free, Mondays.
Info: 215-862-0582, www.phillipsmill.org
LOCAL ARTIST WINS AWARD
Lehigh valley artist James A. DePietro recently was awarded the top prize at the Hunterdon Art Museum in Clinton, N.J.
He will be having a solo exhibition there in November 2016. His award-winning piece, "Deconstruction No. 7: Silence and Stone," is on display at the 2015 Members Exhibition through Jan. 23. Museum hours are 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Tuesday through Sunday.
Info: hunterdonartmuseum.org .
